title: Amunhotep I in the White Crown
description:
Relief representation, in creamy-white limestone, of the head of a king facing right. Before his face are the partial remains of a cartouche.
Condition: Mended from several pieces.

museum_location.name: Old Kingdom to 18th Dynasty, Egyptian Galleries, 3rd Floor

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.title: 71.82
labels.content: This raised relief shows Amunhotep I wearing a royal beard and the tall White Crown of Upper Egypt with a royal uraeus-cobra. The fragment comes from one of several chapels that Amunhotep I built within the Karnak Temple for the god Amun. These chapels imitate Middle Kingdom examples erected by Senwosret I of the Twelfth Dynasty, about four hundred years earlier. Certain features, however—including the curved iris of the eye, a long, curving nose with accentuated nostril, and a raised line around the corner of the mouth—typify Eighteenth Dynasty style.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
